title: Allentown Art Museum finales: Folk Art, Woven Welcome
text:
A last look at the Allentown Art Museum's big summer exhibitions and the culmination of the "Woven Welcome" community art project are highlights of a day of free activities at the museum Sunday, Oct. 11.
Since February more than 9,000 people — individuals, families, students and community groups — have worked in the museum and out to create 350 rug segments in an illustration of the power of collaboration and community. They will be pieced together and presented as a work of public art in the Allentown Arts Park at 3 p.m.
Before the reveal, a panel discussion on art and social practices, community engagement, and do-it-yourself culture will be at 1 p.m., moderated by Julia Marsh, the museum's Curator of Community Engagement.
Inside the museum, view "A Shared Legacy: Folk Art in America," and "Above Zero: Photographs from the Polar Regions by Sam Krisch," which close on Sunday. A guided tour of "Fok Art" will be at 2 p.m.
Ceramic artist Jon Roylance will talk about his decorative raku pottery and functional stoneware in the Museum Store noon-3 p.m.
Kids can enjoy trilingual storytime at 1:30 p.m., with a reading of "Joseph Had a Little Overcoat," a book by Caldecott Medal winner Simms Taback (1999), in English, Hebrew, and Spanish. Suggested age is 3-9.
More info: allentownartmuseum.org , 610-432-4333.
— Jodi Duckett
